intro: Acacia cuthbertsonii subsp. cuthbertsonii, commonly known as the Cuthbertson's wattle, is a shrub native to Western Australia. It features slender, twisted stems and small, bipinnate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces yellow flowers in late winter to early spring, which are clustered in cylindrical spikes. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showing resilience to drought conditions. The subspecies is distinguished by its unique morphology and habitat preferences within the Acacia genus.
taxonomy_art_desc: Acacia cuthbertsonii subsp. cuthbertsonii belongs to the kingdom Plantae. Its phylum is Streptophyta, which includes all land plants and is characterized by the presence of true roots, stems, and leaves. Its class is Equisetopsida, a group that includes ferns and horsetails, known for their ancient lineage and diverse morphological features. Its subclass is Magnoliidae, a group of flowering plants that includes many economically important species and is distinguished by their complex flower structures. Its order is Fabales, which comprises plants with flowers that typically have five petals and include legumes, which are known for their nitrogen-fixing ability. Its family is Fabaceae, commonly known as the legume or pea family, characterized by their pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing capabilities. Its genus is Acacia, a large genus of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive, often thorny appearance and their ability to thrive in arid environments. Its species is Acacia cuthbertsonii, a specific type of acacia native to Australia, known for its ecological significance and unique adaptations to its environment.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia cuthbertsonii subsp. cuthbertsonii is primarily native to the Northern Territory and Western Australia. This subspecies is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions within these areas. It typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to the harsh climate conditions of the region. The plant is often seen in open woodlands and shrublands. Its distribution is closely linked to the environmental conditions of the northern Australian outback.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acacia cuthbertsonii subsp. cuthbertsonii was mainly introduced to South Australia. It is commonly found in coastal areas and sandy soils. This subspecies is known for its distinctive yellow flowers and thorny stems. It is often used in landscaping due to its hardy nature. However, it can become invasive in certain environments if not managed properly.
